description: Smallest k such that k*n+1 is prime.
comments: Conjecture: for every n > 1 there exists a number k < n such that n*k + 1 is a prime. - _Amarnath Murthy_, Apr 17 2001This is true by Dirichlet's theorem on arithmetic progressions: for any pair (r,s) of integers such that gcd(r,s)=1 there are infinitely many primes in the sequence r + k*s; choose r=1 and s=p. - _Joerg Arndt_, Mar 20 2016A stronger conjecture: for every n there exists a number k < 1 + n^(.75) such that n*k + 1 is a prime. I have verified this up to n = 10^6. Also, the expression 1 + n^(.74) does not work as an upper bound (counterexample: n = 19). - _Joseph L. Pe_, Jul 16 2002It is known that, for almost all n, a(n) <= n^2. From Heath-Brown's result (1992) obtained with help of the GRH, it follows that a(n) <= (phi(n)*log(n))^2. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Apr 30 2012Conjecture: a(n) = O(log(n)*log(log(n))). - _Thomas Ordowski_, Oct 17 2014I conjecture the opposite: a(n) / (log n log log n) is unbounded. See A194945 for records in this sequence. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Mar 21 2016

formula: It seems that Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) is asymptotic to (zeta(2)-1)*n*log(n) where zeta(2)-1 = Pi^2/6-1 = 0.6449... . - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 11 2002
example: If n=7, the smallest prime in the sequence 8, 15, 22, 29, ... is 29, so a(7)=4.
